worminfo

  • Articles

    worminfo

    Michael J. Steinbaugh

    2017-01-19

    The goal of the worminfo package is to quickly and simply provide correct, up-to-date annotation data for the entire C. elegans genome. The underlying annotations provided by the gene() function are automatically sourced from WormBase, Ensembl and PANTHER. These source files are saved at the data branch of the worminfo GitHub repository. WormBase is updated on a bi-monthly release schedule. If the source data appears outdated, file an update request on GitHub, and we’ll promptly issue a rebuild.

    Current annotation build information:

    get("build", envir = asNamespace("worminfo"))
    ## $date
## [1] "2017-01-19"
## 
## $ensembl
## [1] "Ensembl Genes 87"
## 
## $panther
## [1] "PANTHER 11.0"
## 
## $rstats
## [1] "R version 3.3.2 (2016-10-31) running on x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0"
## 
## $wormbase
## [1] "WormBase WS256"

    Gene identifier queries

    gene() accepts 4 types of identifiers: gene, name, sequence or class. Output from the function is controlled using the select parameter. The function returns a tibble that can be manipulated using the dplyr package or the base::merge() function. We recommend using dplyr::left_join() to bind these annotations to other data.frames.

    • gene: WormBase gene:
    • sequence: WormBase sequence, aka ORF:
    • name: WormBase name:
    gene("WBGene00004804", format = "gene")
gene("T19E7.2", format = "sequence")
gene("skn-1", format = "name")

    All 3 of these queries return the same result:

    See how these queries all return the same tibble data.frame, but with different sorting.

    You can also return all genes in a named class. For example, let’s get the current list of daf (Dauer Arrest Forming) genes:

    gene("daf", format = "class")
    ## # A tibble: 34 × 3
##      name           gene sequence
##     <chr>          <chr>    <chr>
## 1   daf-1 WBGene00000897  F29C4.1
## 2   daf-2 WBGene00000898 Y55D5A.5
## 3   daf-3 WBGene00000899  F25E2.5
## 4   daf-4 WBGene00000900  C05D2.1
## 5   daf-5 WBGene00000901  W01G7.1
## 6   daf-6 WBGene00000902  F31F6.5
## 7   daf-7 WBGene00000903  B0412.2
## 8   daf-8 WBGene00000904 R05D11.1
## 9   daf-9 WBGene00000905  T13C5.1
## 10 daf-10 WBGene00000906  F23B2.4
## # ... with 24 more rows

    You can perform a keyword search. For example, let’s query all genes that have been implicated in the regulation of worm lifespan:

    gene("lifespan", format = "keyword") %>% head
    ## # A tibble: 6 × 4
##             gene  keyword   sequence   name
##            <chr>    <chr>      <chr>  <chr>
## 1 WBGene00000001 lifespan Y110A7A.10  aap-1
## 2 WBGene00000037 lifespan   Y48B6A.8  ace-3
## 3 WBGene00000038 lifespan   Y48B6A.7  ace-4
## 4 WBGene00000040 lifespan    ZK455.1  aco-1
## 5 WBGene00000041 lifespan   F54H12.1  aco-2
## 6 WBGene00000055 lifespan    F25G6.3 acr-16

    select options

    The gene() function is bundled with source data that can be queried using the select parameter. Here’s the current list of data annotations that can be called with select:

    • biotype
    • blastpHsapiensDescription
    • blastpHsapiensGene
    • blastpHsapiensName
    • blastpPeptide
    • blastpWormpep
    • chromosome
    • class
    • descriptionAutomated
    • descriptionConcise
    • descriptionDetailed
    • descriptionProvisional
    • endPosition
    • ensemblDescription
    • ensemblGeneOntology
    • gene
    • interpro
    • name
    • orthologHsapiens
    • otherIdentifier
    • pantherClass
    • pantherFamilyName
    • pantherGeneOntologyBiologicalProcess
    • pantherGeneOntologyCellularComponent
    • pantherGeneOntologyMolecularFunction
    • pantherPathway
    • pantherSubfamily
    • pantherSubfamilyName
    • rnaiPhenotype
    • sequence
    • startPosition
    • status
    • strand

    When select is not declared, a simple result is returned:

    • gene
    • sequence
    • name

    gene() query examples

    Basic identifiers for skn-1 (bZIP transcription factor):

    gene("skn-1", format = "name") %>% t
    ##          [,1]            
## name     "skn-1"         
## gene     "WBGene00004804"
## sequence "T19E7.2"

    Select WormBase and Ensembl descriptions for sbp-1 (bHLH transcription factor):

    gene("sbp-1",
     format = "name",
     select = "ensemblDescription") %>% t
    ##          [,1]            
## name     "sbp-1"         
## gene     "WBGene00004735"
## sequence "Y47D3B.7"

    RNAi clone identifier queries

    RNA interference libraries are commonly used in C. elegans research. RNAi clones are typically referenced by a gene pair or open reading frame (ORF) sequence, which are often difficult to map to an up-to-date gene identifier. We have written the rnai() function to solve this problem. The function enables a researcher to search for RNAi clones by a gene identifier, or map an RNAi clone by plate location and return the up-to-date WormBase gene identifier. The function also obtains primary and secondary target information from WormBase, which can be informative since many RNAi clones have off-target effects.

    The function has built-in support for the commonly used Ahringer and ORFeome RNAi libraries.

    Finding clones by gene identifier

    Let’s find the locations of sbp-1 in the Ahringer and ORFeome libraries. This can be done easily with the rnai() function, just search by name:

    rnai("sbp-1", format = "name") %>% t
    ##          [,1]                                                                                
## name     "sbp-1"                                                                             
## gene     "WBGene00004735"                                                                    
## sequence "Y47D3B.7"                                                                          
## clone    "ahringer384-III-6-C01, ahringer96-86-B01, orfeome96-10059-H06, orfeome96-11010-G06"

    Alternatively, you can search by WormBase gene identifier or sequence, aka open reading frame (ORF). These queries will return the same result:

    rnai("WBGene00004735", format = "gene")
rnai("Y47D3B.7", format = "sequence")

    Mapping RNAi clones to gene identifiers

    The rnai() function was written to simplify the task of identifying wells of interest in an RNAi screen. You can simply input the well identifiers by plate location, and rnai() will return up-to-date gene identifiers from WormBase.

    Ahringer library

    Here’s how you map wells from the Ahringer library in 384 well format. Note that plate location identifiers must include the chromosome in roman numeral format at the beginning.

    Wells from the Ahringer library in 96 well format are also supported. Since this library has unique plate numbers, the chromosome prefix is not necessary.

    c("ahringer384-III-6C01",
  "ahringer96-86-B01") %>% rnai %>% t
    ##          [,1]                   [,2]               
## clone    "ahringer384-III-6C01" "ahringer96-86-B01"
## gene     "WBGene00004735"       "WBGene00004735"   
## sequence "Y47D3B.7"             "Y47D3B.7"         
## name     "sbp-1"                "sbp-1"

    ORFeome library

    rnai() has mapping support for the ORFeome library, in 96 well format. Plate position should be entered in the same format as seen on the WORFDB. However, the function is flexible, and also supports entries in the historical format (e.g. GHR-11010@G06), or without a separator:

    c("GHR-11010@G06",
  "orfeome96-11010-G06") %>% rnai %>% t
    ##          [,1]             [,2]                 
## clone    "GHR-11010@G06"  "orfeome96-11010-G06"
## gene     "WBGene00004735" "WBGene00004735"     
## sequence "Y47D3B.7"       "Y47D3B.7"           
## name     "sbp-1"          "sbp-1"

    Create a cherrypick library

    Here’s a how to generate a list of ORFeome clones that target the unfolded protein response:

    cherrypick("unfolded protein response",
           ahringer96 = FALSE,
           ahringer384 = FALSE,
           orfeome96 = TRUE) %>% head
    ## # A tibble: 6 × 5
##             gene                   keyword  sequence     name
##            <chr>                     <chr>     <chr>    <chr>
## 1 WBGene00020038 unfolded protein response  R12E2.13     <NA>
## 2 WBGene00002026 unfolded protein response   C12C8.1   hsp-70
## 3 WBGene00004978 unfolded protein response Y47G6A.10    spg-7
## 4 WBGene00007352 unfolded protein response   C06A1.1 cdc-48.1
## 5 WBGene00002147 unfolded protein response   C41C4.4    ire-1
## 6 WBGene00012532 unfolded protein response  Y32F6B.3    crp-1
## # ... with 1 more variables: clone <chr>
